title: Why are all champs/skins gender-locked?
body:
Another game I play that is based on Marvel comics has costumes that change gender. Most Spider-man costumes are Peter Parker, but some are Gwen Stacy or Mayday Parker. 

So I'm wondering why we don't have that in League. Seems like an easy way to reimagine champs, make lots of money, and walk the line between diversity and pandering. Kinda seems like a win/win. Think about a few examples:

- Ivern as a Gaia type
- Graves as an Annie Oakley type
- Zyra with a sorcerer's body
- Lee Sin as a Chun Li type
- Ahri as a sexy dude - the money prints itself
- Xaryah and Rakan in various combinations
- Tryndamere as a Barbarian Sonya type
- Ursula-got - again, the money prints itself!
- Leblanc as a Loki type
- Jinx as a Joker type
- Ezreal as a Samus type

The cool ideas basically never end, so why don't they do any of this?

replies.body: A lot of extra effort for a pretty superficial gimmick?
That's pretty true of every legendary skin, no?

Also they would need to completely change the model for most characters, then they would have to do this for 130+ characters **PLUS** new VA's **PLUS** new animations for walking, running and skills. That's a lot of work for something superficial. That's ore work than typical legendary skins, which are once a year.

Actually that's the exact amount of work for legendary skins and you're thinking of ultimate skins which always have an in-game transformation aspect.

The thing is, just changing a character's model to be the opposite gender then getting new voice lines would not be that difficult. Again, they do it all the time. Ultimate and legendary skins do it every time. They could easily make a gender-swap skin a legendary skin, or go even lazier than that. There are a lot of short-cuts they could take in the development process.

My comment was just to say making a gender swap for what this post implied to as multiple champions isn't really viable.

And i'm not saying they can't do it, but taking months to maybe a year just to make  a gender swap, seems like a misallocation of resources :/. Usually riot reserves legendary skins to go in a new creative direction and the effort to just have a gender swap doesn't seem to justiffy the effort. In addition players will b*tch that they're paying legendary skin money on just a gender swap. (They already b*tch over trivialities) 

Plus some champ (eg braum and all female champs except Illaoi) will need not legendary skin resources, but new champion/ rework level resources just for a gender swap
tl dr ends doesn't justify the means and just a gender swap isn't legendary skin level

The Riot post on this exact post says they've wanted to do it, so that argument is invalid. And your last statement is so incredibly wrong, I want to scream. That's called sexism and I'm not okay with it. No, absolutely, men and women _for the most part_ look different physically. But suggesting that a whole new champ would need to be created just to add/remove boobs is ludicrous. It would literally just be a voice/model replacement, which legendary skins do. A new champ requires a kit build (which takes a long time due to implications with the meta), lore, and unique character design, and that's all on top of the technical skin-related work. What you said is so ignorant, I can't even.

I can't even.
Legendaries usually don't involve getting a new VA.
In most cases it really wouldn't be that difficult to just lower the pitch of the VO.

Its a neat idea, but I don't think its a plausible one for a few reasons. One that was mentioned by others is opportunity cost. Creating a Genderbent version of a Champ is roughly the same work as creating an entire Champion (from a Visual design standpoint). New VO, new model, new animations - its the same work that would go into a new Champion.

Also, Riot talks a lot about a Champion's "silhouette", the visual read on a Champion so that you immediately know who you're looking at. With 130+ Champions you immediately need to know if the character coming out of the brush is Caitlin or Graves, and if Graves is Annie Oakley, you may risk blurring those lines even more. Certainly you could argue all day long about how you'd make a certain Champion maintain the same visual read while being genderbent but it still weakens that element of immediate identification, which can bring up some tactical/balance issues.

Personally I'd be more interested to see the Champion designs themselves be a little more diverse - more androgynous or genderfluid characters, but that risks flaring up the community if poorly handled.

I see your point, but think about it like this...

Let's pretend that Superman is a champ on SR. His costumes are Classic, Cyborg, Superboy, and Ultraman.

Art team says, "hey, let's do a Supergirl costume!" The reply is, "that's too different and confusing, let's do a Steel or black Resurrection costume instead." That doesn't make sense when Supergirl is immediately recognizable, and Steel and the black resurrection costume look head-to-toe different.

Why would they have a totally different feel, personality, or even animations on a gender-swap skin? I think part of the appeal would be seeing how those existing parts of a champ's in-game personality carry over. Graves is a good example, because I think it would be hilarious to see a gritty, surly woman dashing around with a shotgun. For another example, Vayne, Quinn, RIven, etc have super butch animations that would translate fine.

Well they'd all need new VO's, and they'd have to pay more voice actors for that, and make entirely new models, and all that stuff takes time.

Plus, gender-swapping a character tends to sort of... devalue the original character, in my opinion. It's not a character with a unique place in the world, it's someone who can be swapped out for another person of another gender. Legendary skins have major changes, sure, but they almost always change the personality. This would basically be paying to get the same character, and I'd rather they get a unique, cool look.

Also Joker actually plans. Jinx does not. She's closer to Harley Quinn, but doesn't reach Joker's brain power level (actual joker, not the recent "joker as nothing more than a complete psychopath." He's a psycho, but he's got other stuff about him. Recent stuff dumps everything besides the psycho.) (besides lego batman. That movie was fantastic.)

I agree to some extent about staying true to characters, but there are quite a lot of champs where it doesn't make any difference or even opens up new ways to tell a character's story.

Take Zyra for example. She's definitely had other forms, and possibly other bodies. Strictly speaking, the champ's identity doesn't really change if Zyra possessed a male or female sorcerer.

Because why can't you be satisfied as what they are?
And it is crossing a slippery slope when it comes to this topic.
Because genderbending is lame and belongs on tumblr and deviantart.
That would involve making completely new skeletons for most champions on top of new models.

Because males and females have vastly different body shapes. Riot would have to build a new model from the ground up for each champion, and would have to make it _recognizable as that champion_. {{champion:427}} would be pretty easy (only two living trees, and both vastly different, although showing that Ivern's inverted would be hard), but would an inverted {{champion:55}} even still _feel_ like Kat? And champions like {{champion:412}}, whom are pretty much a-sex, would be impossible, not to mention the difficulty of swapping {{champion:203}} ((fe)male in their particular case is symbolic).


And that's just the base appearance. Animations would change, voices would be different, hell, even _ability descriptions_ would have to be changed. And it'd have to change for all of the thousands of skins in League.

Those are some good examples of champs you wouldn't do or wouldn't be worth the effort. Kat's an interesting example, though. Strictly speaking, there isn't anything about her that's uniquely female. But her gender is the only way we know that Noxus is a strict meritocracy, and that tells us more about every Noxian, not just Kat. 

I think that's a pretty good example of why *not* to change them. It's also an example of how gender can be used for good storytelling.

On the other hand....you have champs like Talon, Veigar, etc. that would only change aesthetically without any consequence to the story. That sort of Pacman - Ms. Pacman cosmetic change is what I think would be cool.
Let's bring special attention to the VO, considering how long it takes for regular VOs to be updated.
